sentences.sentence: Raymond Fan's espousal of Chinese Communist Party talking points in defence of the Orwellian "national security law" that Beijing intends to inflict on Hong Kong by diktat illustrates the extent to which Chinese and Hong Kong government officials are aloof and disconnected from the daily reality experienced by Hongkongers ("Hong Kong security law good for all parties", Letters, May 29).As an expatriate based in Hong Kong, I speak from first-hand experience when I say that the peaceful democracy protesters represent the mainstream opinions of Hongkongers and threaten nobody but the fragile egos of the arrogant authoritarians who control the levers of power.The only threat to the safety of international businesses emanates from CCP hardliners like former Hong Kong chief executive Leung Chun-ying, who recently demanded that people boycott HSBC because the British-headquartered bank has refrained from commenting on or supporting the "national security law".Will Mr Fan please explain how international businesses can feel safe in Hong Kong if an institution as sizeable as the territory's largest bank is subject to political blackmail by senior government figures?Nicholas TamVictoria, Hong Kong'Benefits' of Chinese lawseem to elude residentsReferring to Raymond Fan's detailed explanation of the situation in Hong Kong, it would be beneficial if he were to also forward this to the South China Morning Post so that the residents of Hong Kong may gain a better understanding of the many benefits that are apparently being generously bestowed upon them.Eric J MarshallDoncaster, VicCarbon capture won'thelp stop emissionsI wish I could share the optimism displayed by David Byers and Peter Cook regarding the potential of carbon capture and storage (CCS) technology to cut greenhouse gas emissions ("Hydrogen and CCS could be the energy road map winners", June 1).In principle, the idea of capturing the carbon dioxide emitted from fossil fuels is very appealing.

In practice, its applicability on a large enough scale is still hypothetical.What is certain though is that the prospect of CCS offers fossil-fuel emitters a licence to continue their operations unabated for years to come.

This worry seems particularly justified by the fact that its proponent - Energy Minister Angus Taylor - has always prioritised the wellbeing of the fossil fuel industry to the task of emissions reduction.No centralised investment plan - like Mr Taylor's technology road map - can be really technology neutral.
Do we really want a technology-neutral road map to carbon reductions?

Let's put a price on carbon and let the free market solve the problem.Simone BelliWollstonecraft, NSWVictoria right to geton board with ChinaNo wonder US Secretary of State Mike Pompeo is upset about Victoria joining the Belt and Road Initiative ("US backtracks over intel sharing threat", May 24).The BRI program involves China building large amounts of infrastructure, including 5G technology, and providing finance to many countries.Huawei has the best 5G technology in the world and its R&D spend is many times that of any US company.The BRI links China's trains carrying cargo infrastructure all the way to Europe and it includes many strategic ports.

The US controls the waterways but it cannot control the BRI.China lends far more money than the IMF and World Bank combined - about $1.5 trillion in direct loans and trade credits to more than 150 countries.

Those countries probably repay the loans using yuan instead of US dollars.Countries that the US wishes to control and destroy, such as Iran, are part of the BRI, which increases their power in the Middle East.

Turkey is also a very important country taking part in the BRI.The other Chinese threat to US world hegemony is that China is setting up digital currency transaction capability in many countries, much like Alibaba, and that can be used for cross-border transactions, bypassing SWIFT and the US dollar.China is on a very strategic path to success, so the state of Victoria was right to join the BRI.Louise O'BrienWollstonecraft, NSWDitch payroll tax to giveworkers a pay riseEmma Dawson may be right ("We won't see an Accord 2.0", June 1) but there is a way to achieve reform and lift all wages, while at the same time freezing labour costs.Abolish state payroll tax and let business pass the money to workers as the largest lift in real wages in decades and kick-start an era of federal-state tax reform.Why fight over minimum wage rates when you could remedy Australia's greatest wages theft, the $25 billion state governments clip every year?Given Canberra's COVID accounting error, use that to reimburse the states for abolishing payroll tax, and deliver what everyone can agree on - a 5 per cent lift in real wages.Simon JemisonMelbourne, VicIntegrity bill didn't haveintegrity to begin withAs "an act of goodwill", Scott Morrison has announced he is ditching his draft Ensuring Integrity Bill ("PM seeks union work accord", May 27).Thus we hope there is a bipartisan spirit that allows the government and the ACTU to explore industrial relations reform.

Well yes, but the existence of this draft union-busting legislation was "an act of badwill" in first place!Ditching extreme attitudes is a blessed relief, also to be welcomed in the climate change issue, not a positive cause for praise.Malcolm CameronCamberwell, VicQld tourism operatorsshould take to streetsBy keeping the borders closed, Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk is rapidly and systematically destroying Queensland tourism.While complaining about their imminent closure or bankruptcy, resort and hotel owners are doing very little to combat it.Scott Morrison has done an enviable job in controlling COVID-19 but appears too timid to confront the recalcitrant Premier.Surely Queensland tourism should be taking a more conspicuous stand.
An example might be to march on Government House in Brisbane.

Although temporarily closed, this should not deter them.Neville MillsNoosaville, QldMore 'we', less 'me'from the PM, pleaseThe national cabinet and evidence-based input has clearly been a vehicle for improved decision making and subsequent confidence in public administration, and a shift towards that missing component, trust.The decision to extend the life of the national cabinet past the current crisis has the potential to improve that trust, provided that the decisions coming out are seen to be consensual and non-partisan.

It would be a great improvement if Scott Morrison could move away from the use of the first person singular "I" and "me" to the more inclusive first person plural pronouns "we" and "us" when announcing decisions of the cabinet.Peter GartonHumpty Doo, NT

documents.result_message: Our detector is highly confident that the text is written entirely by a human.

Turkey is also a very important country taking part in the BRI.The other Chinese threat to US world hegemony is that China is setting up digital currency transaction capability in many countries, much like Alibaba, and that can be used for cross-border transactions, bypassing SWIFT and the US dollar.China is on a very strategic path to success, so the state of Victoria was right to join the BRI.Louise O'BrienWollstonecraft, NSWDitch payroll tax to giveworkers a pay riseEmma Dawson may be right ("We won't see an Accord 2.0", June 1) but there is a way to achieve reform and lift all wages, while at the same time freezing labour costs.Abolish state payroll tax and let business pass the money to workers as the largest lift in real wages in decades and kick-start an era of federal-state tax reform.Why fight over minimum wage rates when you could remedy Australia's greatest wages theft, the $25 billion state governments clip every year?Given Canberra's COVID accounting error, use that to reimburse the states for abolishing payroll tax, and deliver what everyone can agree on - a 5 per cent lift in real wages.Simon JemisonMelbourne, VicIntegrity bill didn't haveintegrity to begin withAs "an act of goodwill", Scott Morrison has announced he is ditching his draft Ensuring Integrity Bill ("PM seeks union work accord", May 27).Thus we hope there is a bipartisan spirit that allows the government and the ACTU to explore industrial relations reform. Well yes, but the existence of this draft union-busting legislation was "an act of badwill" in first place!Ditching extreme attitudes is a blessed relief, also to be welcomed in the climate change issue, not a positive cause for praise.Malcolm CameronCamberwell, VicQld tourism operatorsshould take to streetsBy keeping the borders closed, Premier Annastacia Palaszczuk is rapidly and systematically destroying Queensland tourism.While complaining about their imminent closure or bankruptcy, resort and hotel owners are doing very little to combat it.Scott Morrison has done an enviable job in controlling COVID-19 but appears too timid to confront the recalcitrant Premier.Surely Queensland tourism should be taking a more conspicuous stand. An example might be to march on Government House in Brisbane. Although temporarily closed, this should not deter them.Neville MillsNoosaville, QldMore 'we', less 'me'from the PM, pleaseThe national cabinet and evidence-based input has clearly been a vehicle for improved decision making and subsequent confidence in public administration, and a shift towards that missing component, trust.The decision to extend the life of the national cabinet past the current crisis has the potential to improve that trust, provided that the decisions coming out are seen to be consensual and non-partisan. It would be a great improvement if Scott Morrison could move away from the use of the first person singular "I" and "me" to the more inclusive first person plural pronouns "we" and "us" when announcing decisions of the cabinet.Peter GartonHumpty Doo, NT
